p: From 2009 to December 2018, only three cases acquired by visitors to the Maldives were reported in the literature or in the ProMED International Society of Infectious Diseases database, one from France [ 14] and two from Germany [ 15], all in 2009. Since 2019, concomitantly with a dengue outbreak, the Maldives health authorities have reported an epidemic of CHIKV, with 1,736 cases reported as of the 31st December 2019 [ 6]. As experienced in the United States Virgin Islands in 2014, current and possibly recurrent chikungunya outbreaks in the Maldives could have major human and economic impact [ 16]. Several factors may have contributed to this re-emergence including waning anti-CHIKV herd immunity in the local population over time, a recent re-introduction of the virus due to the flux of tourists or migrant workers, notably in areas less reached in 2006, and changes in viral strains and vector density [ 17].
